metadata.title: Lipid nano scale cargos for the protection and delivery of food bioactive ingredients and nutraceuticals

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Trends in Food Science & Technology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/tifs
Review
Lipid nano scale cargos for the protection and delivery of food bioactive ingredients and nutraceuticals
Sahar Akhavana, Elham Assadpoura, Iman Katouziana,b, Seid Mahdi Jafaria,∗
a Department of Food Materials and Process Design Engineering, Gorgan University of Agricultural Sciences and Natural Resources, Gorgan, Iran bNano-encapsulation in the Food, Nutraceutical, and Pharmaceutical Industries Group (NFNPIG), Universal Scientific Education and Research Network (USERN), Tehran, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nanoencapsulation Nanoliposome Nanoemulsion Lipid nanocarriers Nutraceuticals
A B S T R A C T
Background: The encapsulation and liberation technologies for bioactive food ingredients has opened the door to innovative and significant applications in food, nutrition, and pharmaceutical fields via the employment of nanotechnology. Coating materials in the formulation of nanocapsules are mostly lipid, carbohydrate or proteinbased. The nanoencapsulation procedure in the food and nutraceutical areas involves the incorporation of natural ingredients, such as volatile additives, polyphenols, aromas, colors, vitamins, enzymes, oils and antimicrobial compounds in nano-sized capsules, providing the opportunities for higher stability and retention for the sensitive molecules against decomposition and loss of nutritional value during the production process or delivery along with offering a sustained release. Scope and approach: This review highlights the most recent nanoencapsulation advancements along with the formulations mainly based on lipid components; i.e., nanoemulsions, nanoliposomes and nanostructured lipid carriers in terms of preparation strategies, their classes, composition, attributes, analysis techniques, worked examples, and implementation in functional foods along with their upcoming evolution and future trends. Key findings and conclusions: Nanocapsules with lipid formulations are possible alternatives to micro-sized carriers owing to the enormous surface area and the following features which they offer, such as improved solubility, high bioavailability and establishment of sustained liberation of the nanoencapsulated food constituents and nutraceuticals.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Encapsulation mainly comprises the entrapment process of different biological or chemical cargos with the aim of enabling controlled release under specific circumstances. Indeed, the objective of this case is to shield the bioactive components from the external destructive conditions while permitting minuscule molecules to enter or exit the surrounding membrane. Imagine the conventional type of this process in which the capsule is a tiny circular object coated with a homogenous wall all around it. The encased material is referred to as the core, while the membrane is sometimes called the shell, coating, wall material, or matrix (Mahdavi, Jafari, Ghorbani, & Assadpoor, 2014). Encapsulation technique has entered the field of food science for more than 60 years as an efficient solution to shield the bioactive components against external environmental factors and/or unwanted chemical interactions until release is desired (Sekhon, 2010). The micro/nanoencapsulation strategy has captured food industry by a storm and the high number of publications conveys the growing interest in this applicable technology.
Micro/nanocapsule properties may be altered to achieve the best conditions including configuration, mode of release, particle size, ultimate physical architecture and cost. Prior to the engineering of the delivery systems, it is necessary to determine the functions of the payloads and what they add to the ultimate value of the product in order to choose the best carrier for the entire system. Encapsulated particles are termed as “microcapsules” as the size breadth is between 0.2 and 5000 μm, macrocapsules when the scale is higher than 5000 μm and nanocapsules under 1.0 μm. Nanocapsules offer a broad range of interesting features over their micro-sized counterparts as they hold more surface area, have enhanced solubility, significantly higher bioaccessibility and the ability of controlled liberation in the specific site of action (Katouzian & Jafari, 2016; Faridi Esfanjani, & Jafari, 2016).

sections.text:

How to choose the appropriate nanoencapsualtion technique? The answer to this question depends on the intended application together with the physicochemical attributes of the core and wall materials, release mode, process cost, etc. (Pyo, Müller, & Keck, 2017, pp. 114–137).

sections.heading: 3. Lipid-based vehicles for nanoencapsulation of food bioactive compounds
sections.text:
Lipid-based nanoencapsulation bodies are well-suited carriers, which are being rapidly developed for a variety of purposes. Other nanocarriers consisted of carbohydrate or protein building blocks are not suitable candidates for the full scale up process due to the employment of intricate chemical and thermal processes which cannot be completely monitored. Nevertheless, lipid-based nanocarriers can be applied in the industrial scale and provide higher entrapment efficiency plus low toxicity (Tamjidi, Shahedi, Varshosaz, & Nasirpour, 2013). Most of the bioactive ingredients including polyphenols, fatty acids, lipophillic vitamins and nutraceuticals, aromas and preservatives are intrinsically hydrophobic. For the accommodation of these lipophilic agents, normally oil in water dispersions are prepared. Besides, the availability of digestible lipid facilitates the intestinal absorption of bioactives since they are able to solubilize and carry the hydrophobic molecules (McClements, 2012). Hence, the foregoing advantages hold lipid-based nanocarriers as robust and flexible delivery vectors (Tamjidi et al., 2013).
Several types of lipid-based nanovehicles have been engineered to date. The leading lipid nanocarriers which are introduced in different literature include nanoemulsions, nanoliposomes, nanostructured lipid carriers and solid lipid nanoparticles (Jafari, Fathi, & Mandala, 2015). In the upcoming subsections, these vectors are discussed along with their preparation strategies plus their contemporary applications in the food and nutraceutical sectors.

sections.heading: 3.1. Nanoliposomes
sections.text:
Over the last decades, there has been a tremendous advancement in the preparation, detection and administration of liposomes as carriers of pharmaceutical agents as well as nutrients. The term liposome originates from two Greek words, lipos (fat) and soma (body or structure), meaning an envelope composed of fat encompass the aqueous payload (s) or compartment(s) (Mozafari, Johnson, Hatziantoniou, & Demetzos., 2008a). Liposomes are tiny, spherical amphiphilic lipid vesicles bearing an aqueous internal cavity. The lipids are usually phospholipids akin to the bilayer morphology present in the cell membranes (Fig. 1A).
Considering the processing conditions and the chemical structure, liposomes have one or a set of concentric bilayers. Accordingly, Liposomes are usually characterized by the total number of lamellae and size (Mozafari et al., 2008a; Mozafari et al., 2008b; Mozafari & Mortazavi, 2005).
The formulation protocol of liposomes includes the interactions between the aqueous moiety and amphiphilic lipids. The polar head series of the phospholipids are oriented in the location of the aqueous phase of the internal and external media and the hydrophobic tails are associated with the bilayer. The presence of both lipid and aqueous moieties enable the entrapment, delivery and liberation of water-soluble, lipid-soluble, and amphiphilic compounds (Fang, Fang, Liu, & Su, 2008). According to the previously mentioned capabilities of liposomes, they are undoubtedly robust and flexible delivery systems. Also, Current clinical and biological studies have approved several health benefits including liver protection, memory enhancement and lowering the uptake of cholesterol (Mozafari et al., 2008a). Furthermore, liposomes offer the following interesting features:
○ Controlled delivery system ○ Eco-friendly and nontoxic properties ○ Developed solubility rate of fat-based amphiphilic bioactives ○ Enhanced bioavailability of nutrients
The term nanoliposome is exclusively devised to nanoscale lipid vesicles since liposome generally covers a broad group of lipid vesicles in terms of size, which starts at 10 nm and may reach several micrometers (Demirci, Caglar, Cakir, & Gülseren, 2017, pp. 74–113). Nanoliposomes share the same physical, compositional and thermodynamic characteristics with liposomes, however their bioavailability is much higher than the conventional liposomes.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Techniques for nanoliposome preparation
sections.text:
Typically, the required amount of energy is introduced into the system for the fabrication of both liposomes and nanoliposomes. To date, different preparation methods have been expanded and optimized (summarized in Table 1) and several comprehensive revisions have been published to get a deep insight on the preparation techniques of liposomes (Santana, Perrechil, & Cunha, 2013).
The entire preparation strategies involve four fundamental stages (Ghorbanzade, Jafari, Akhavan, & Hadavi, 2017): (a) drying down lipids from an organic solvent, (b) scattering the lipid in an aqueous media via high energy means, (c) purifying the ultimate yield and finally, (d) analyzing the generated nanoliposome. Traditional techniques are not effective enough for the generation of complex nanoliposomes with respect to the handling of tiny particle sizes and low entrapment efficiency. Today, high-throughput approaches, such as extrusion, microfluidization, ultrasonication and freeze-thawing are administered for the production of nanoliposomes (Maherani, ArabTehrany, Kheirolomoom, Cleymand, & Linder, 2012).
Nearly all the foregoing techniques are able to yield minuscule and monolithic structures with dramatically higher stability. Nonetheless, only a few of these preparation procedures can find proper application on the industrial scale. Indeed, the principal barriers in the manufacturing process include the remaining of utilized organic solvents, physical and chemical lability, administration of synthetic solvents and detergents for dissolvation, the lack of a continuous and practical large scale manufacturing process and affordability (Mortazavi, Mohammadabadi, Khosravi-Darani, & Mozafari, 2007).

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Application of nanoliposomes in the food and nutraceutical industries
sections.text:
The beneficial properties of liposomes render them suitable candidates for utilization in different areas of science and technology, including the fundamental studies of membrane composition or function and the delivery of bioactive compounds. Considering the previously mentioned unique attributes, the use of such carriers are welcomed in the food industry, their application range from the shielding of sensitive ingredients to the improvement of the efficacy of food additives (Torchilin, 2006, pp. 1–8). Originally, liposomes served as membrane models owing to their resemblance to bilayer lipid cell membranes. They are able to mimic the behavior of natural cell membranes and this pattern is mostly useful in formulating drugs which are able to target membranes with a certain arrangement or to study the stability and decomposition of cell membranes in biochemical reactions.
Nanoliposomes and proteoliposomes (liposomes accommodating one or more proteins) are capable of retaining a broad range of bioactive substances for further application in different areas, especially the food industry. In the food sector, nanoliposomes are typically implemented to deliver protein assemblies, vitamins, enzymes, antioxidants, aromas and natural colors (Mozafari, 2005). Table 2 provides the recent applications of the nanoliposomes in the food industry together with a brief overview of the relevant explorations.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. Drawbacks and prospects of nanoliposomes
sections.text:
Nanoliposomes have been incorporated into the food products with
the aim of food fortification and production of nutritional supplements. However, along with the beneficial attributes that these nanocarriers offer they still have their drawbacks including lack of stability under the ingestion circumstances (low pH and digestive enzymes), low loading space for the payloads, unclearness of the interactions which exist between the wall and core materials, and the high cost of foodgrade raw materials for nanoliposome preparation. Consequently, the current research programs have focused on breaking these barriers and expand the application of nanoliposomes to larger scales. Recently, milk-fat-globule-membrane phospholipid, which is industrially derived from dairy waste effluent like buttermilk, are taken into account to generate liposomes. Lastly, there has also been some scientific endeavor to limit the digestion process of liposomes by altering their surface properties.

sections.heading: 3.2. Nanoemulsions
sections.text:
The term emulsion is referred to a system consisted of two immiscible liquids in which one component is dispersed in the form of droplets (the dispersed or internal phase) throughout the other component (the continuous or external phase) (Jafari et al., 2008b). Food emulsions normally belong to either oil-in-water (O/W), water-in-oil (W/O) or double emulsions (Fig. 1B). As reported by (McClements, 2004), emulsions are categorized into micro- (10–100 nm), mini (nano)- (100–1000 nm), and macro-emulsions (0.5–100mm) concerning the size of droplets. Most of the emulsion properties, such as stability, appearance, color and shelf-life scale directly with the emulsion droplet size and size distributions.
Nano-emulsions (submicron-size droplets) is placed among normal and microemulsions, which fits in the size range of 50–200 nm
(transparent) or up to 500 nm that presents a blurred image (McClements, 2012). Nano-emulsions have superiority over ordinary emulsions (micron-size droplets) with respect to the following exclusive features (Esfanjani, Jafari, Assadpoor, & Mohammadi, 2015; Mohammadi, Jafari, Esfanjani, & Akhavan, 2016a, b; Faridi Esfanjani, Jafari, & Assadpour, 2017):
○ Ultra-fine droplets steer toward a tremendous decline in the gravity force and Brownian motion is adequate for overcoming gravity; i.e., no creaming or sedimentation takes place during storage. ○ Flocculation (formation of large droplets by attractive interactions) process is hindered due to the tiny size of the droplets. As a result, this phenomenon enables the network to maintain its dispersed state with no separation. ○ Coalescence (forming of large droplets as small droplets merge into each other) is another undesirable fact that is prevented when the size of droplets decrease since the configuration of the droplets are non-deformable and hence surface alterations are hindered. likewise, the significant surfactant film thickness, which is in line with droplet radius, prevents any thinning or damage to the liquid film between the droplets. Besides, temperature, ionic strength, solubility of the ingredients, additives, the used level of emulsifiers and the chemistry of components determine the occurrence of this phenomenon. ○ Microemulsions usually require a high level of surfactants during their fabrication that is normally in the region of 20% and even higher than this value but nano-emulsions are prepared at much lower surfactant levels, which make them ideal candidates for industrial purposes. ○ Exhibiting transparent optical properties (just as observed in

microemulsions). ○ The small size of the droplets triggers the monodisperse deposition
on substrates. Besides, spreading, wetting and permittivity is raised owing to the low surface tension of the entire matrix plus the existence of low interfacial tension in the O/W droplets. ○ Microemulsions are recognized for their thermodynamic stability, however nano-emulsions are merely kinetically stable. On the other hand, nano-emulsions are not completely stable networks and may experience coalescence, flocculation and even Ostwald ripening. Nonetheless, with an organized design of the matrix constituents along with the preparation method, desired nano-emulsions with perfect kinetic stability are obtained. ○ Nanoemulsions have toxicological safety, high level of the lipid moiety along with the scale-up potential. ○ The nanosized emulsions not only augment the stability of the blend but also contributes to the enhanced bioavailability of the encased nutrients.
Overall, the protracted stability of nanoemulsions that induces a
transparent/translucent appearance by the aid of their small droplet size makes them practical carriers in a broad range of applications. The growing interest in the exertion of nanoemulsions has enhanced dramatically over the last years considering the numerous publications and revisions on this concept (Assadpour, Maghsoudlou, Jafari, Ghorbani, & Aalami, 2016a,b; Mehrnia, Jafari, Makhmal-Zadeh, & Maghsoudlou, 2017, 2016; Rao & McClements, 2011).

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Production of nanoemulsions
sections.text:
The physicochemical attributes of nano-emulsions are closely related to the thermodynamic status, preparation techniques plus the stepwise addition of the building blocks. These structures are fabricated either by high-energy emulsification or dispersion approaches. In addition, low-energy emulsification is another interesting technique by which spontaneous formation of nano-emulsions is carried out (Table 3).
3.2.1.1. High-energy emulsification methods. The common types of this production technique comprise high-pressure homogenization, high

shear mixing, microfluidization, electrified coaxial liquid jets and ultrasonication, which have been reviewed previously by Jafari, Assadpoor, Bhandari, et al. (2008) and McClements (2012). Seekkuarachchi, Tanaka, and Kumazawa (2006) also offered a useful description of high-energy emulsification modes. High-energy procedures provide ultra-fine droplets, however they are not recommended for sensitive and labile molecules, such as peptides or proteins.
3.2.1.2. Low-energy emulsification methods. Nano-emulsions can be generated spontaneously by monitoring the physicochemical traits of the whole system (Assadpour et al., 2016a, b; Mehrnia, Jafari, Makhmal-Zadeh, & Maghsoudlou, 2016, 2017). This is the premise of the condensation or low-energy emulsification methods comprising phase transitions induced by altering the parameters which influence the HLB of the matrix, such as temperature, electrolyte load, etc., or catastrophic inversion imposed by enhancing the fraction of the dispersed moiety (Santana et al., 2013). Other low-energy
emulsification strategies include the procedures like phase inversion temperature (PIT) or phase inversion composition (PIC). PIT method involves modification of the solubility of polyoxyethylene-type nonionic surfactants together with temperature (Perazzo, Preziosi, & Guido, 2015). Colloidosomes, Cubosomes and microfluidic channels are also other means of fabricating nanoemulsions.
The surfactant is water-soluble at low temperatures, while by heating and the following water loss from the polyoxyethylene chains it becomes water-insoluble. At low temperatures, the surface active agent exhibits an immense positive spontaneous curvature forming oilswollen blend (or O/W microemulsions) that may be adjacent to an excess oil phase. Inversely, after the heating process, the spontaneous curvature tends to be negative and water swollen reverse micelles (or W/O microemulsions) are adjacent to the excess water phase. At a certain temperature called “hydrophilic–lipophilic balance (HLB) temperature”, the spontaneous curvature reaches zero and a bicontinuous microemulsion phase possessing both water and oil moieties coexists with the set of excess water and oil mixture (Schubert & Müller-

Grinding in a powder mill (50–100 μm) 4. Dispersing the powder in an aqueous surfactant dispersion medium (pre-mix) 5. High pressure homogenization at room temperature or below

Goymann, 2003). The methodology of the PIT emulsification is built on the significantly low interfacial tensions at the HLB temperature that potentiates emulsification. Yet, even at the HLB temperature that emulsification is driven spontaneously, coalescence pace is extremely rapid and thus the emulsions are highly unstable. Through the quick cooling or heating process at the HLB temperature, kinetically stable emulsions (O/W or W/O, respectively) can be fabricated with extremely tiny droplet size and narrow size distribution. In case that the cooling or heating procedure is not rapid, coalescence is the upcoming result and the emergence of polydispersed coarse emulsions is the outcome. The discussed methods have several limitations including consumption of high levels of surfactants plus the accurate selection of surfactant–cosurfactant admix and they are not appropriate for further applications in large-scale industrial practices (Seekkuarachchi et al., 2006).

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Application of nanoemulsions for the encapsulation of food bioactive ingredients
sections.text: Today, the forerunners in the food sector are grappling with the fabrication of nanoemulsions from label-friendly components so that the novel food products can find proper applications. Many food ingredients and cuisines exist in the form of emulsions, e.g. beverages, butter, dressings, desserts, soups, sauces, in which most of them belong to the category of oil-in-water emulsions (Jafari et al., 2015). Nanoemulsion is a novel nutrition-delivery system with outstanding properties in the food industry. Table 4, covers the successful researches of employing nanoemulsions to accommodate food bioactive components and nutraceuticals, such as vitamins, aromas, food colorants, antimicrobial agents, antioxidants, etc.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Drawbacks of employing nanoemulsions
sections.text:
In spite of the discussed advantages, nanoemulsions have become popular just in recent years. Nano-emulsions are prepared via different routes and by implementing special apparatus like high pressure homogenizers as well as sonicators. Such equipment (such as the Microfluidizer) has lately been utilized in the laboratories. In addition, nanoemulsions may undergo unwanted phenomena, such as Ostwald ripening (Rao & McClements, 2011), flocculation, membrane permeability and further liberation of bioactives, gelling, creaming, and particle attraction during storage (McClements, 2012), however by choosing the right type of surfactant and controlling the surface charges these phenomena can be minimized. There is a perception in the food business that the fabrication of nanoemulsions is not profitable. Accordingly, expensive equipment together with the usage of high concentrations of emulsifiers render them costly products.
Nanoemulsions are labile at lower pH values and the controlled liberation process does not take place due to their small size and the liquid nature of the vehicle (Trotta, Debernardi, & Caputo, 2003). Moreover, the chemical stability of nanoemulsions is not completely clear. On the other hand, there is a lack of understanding on the precise method of submicron droplets production plus the function of surfactants, cosurfactants and the chemical interfacial reactions that impart their roles in the production of nano-emulsions. For instance, few formulation chemists are familiar with the PIT concept and the employment of this theory to prepare tiny emulsion droplets.
Having discussed the abovementioned difficulties, several industries notably the pharmaceutical and food industries have already released nanoemulsions in the market and in the following couple of years, the overall benefits and impacts will be evaluated. Acceptance of nanoemulsions as innovative formulations depends on consumer's attitude towards these nano-scale products. With the arrival of new instruments for the generation of nanocarriers and the competition between leading companies, the preparation cost of nanoemulsion will decline and probably reach the price of regular macroemulsions. The ongoing research in functions of surfactants will contribute to the fabrication of cost-effective and efficient emulsifier systems to be applied in the formulation of nanoemulsions. Ultimately, the key role of the phase
behavior is inevitable in the preparation of nanoemulsions which affects the final product considerably.

sections.heading: 3.3. Nanostructured lipid carriers
sections.text:
Considering all the discussed advantages of lipid-based nano-delivery systems mentioned in the beginning of Section 3, it is fair enough that lots of work were undertaken in line to these nanocarriers, particularly the nanostructured lipid carriers for their further application in various pharmaceutical and food practices which is discussed below. As demonstrated in Fig. 1C, lipid-based nanocarriers in the food sector comprise Solid Lipid Nanoparticles (SLNs) and Nanostructured Lipid Carriers (NLCs) (Fang et al., 2008). SLNs are actually originated from O/W emulsions with some modifications by which the liquid lipid (oil) is substituted by a solid lipid that maintains its solid state within the body temperature. The emergence and advancement of SLNs are a major progress in the field of nanoscience. SLNs successfully compensate the limitations of conventional nanovehicles (emulsions, polymeric nanoparticles and liposomes) by providing high stability, biocompatibility, targeted delivery, retention of bioactive molecules, sustained release of bioactive ingredients, affordable and straightforward scale-up methods (Müller, Petersen, Hommoss, & Pardeike, 2007). However, these beneficial nanovehicles have their own limitations, which are introduced below.
○ low free space for the confinement of bioactive molecules ○ loss of bioactive ingredients via expulsion during storage ○ considerably high level of water aqueous SLN solutions (70–95%) ○ switch to the low energy, partially uniform β modification in the
storage period ○ aggregation and particle enlargement ○ unforeseen gelation behavior ○ shift of polymorphic states
Therefore, in order to dispel the drawbacks of SLNs, NLCs were introduced in the 1990s as the next generation of SLNs (Üner & Yener, 2007). Unlike the composition of SLNs, NLCs are prepared by the mixture of both solid and liquid lipids with controlled levels that possess improved capacity of bioactive retention along with controlled release attributes. The melting point of the final composition is reduced compared to the pure solid lipid, furthermore the ultimate particles do not maintain their solid structure at the ambient and body temperature (Lasoń, Sikora, & Ogonowski, 2013).
NLCs possess many amorphous crystals within their structure, which establish a larger room for the bioactive molecules and lower the expulsion rate of bioactive compounds (Tamjidi et al. 2013). The introduced amount of liquid lipids in the matrix play a dynamic role in hindering the crystallization process by blending “spatially” different compounds (Radtke & Müller, 2001). This procedure yields tangible differences in the particle matrix structure (Fig. 1C). Yet, scholars prefer NLCs over SLNs owing to their lipid anti-recrystallization attributes that prevent the expulsion of bioactive payload (Müller et al., 2007).
Three classes of NLCs are (I) the imperfect structured type, (II) the amorphous type, and (III) the multiple types (Fig. 2). All the aforementioned models provide the circumstances for the formation of compact particle dispersions (> 30–95%) plus the augmented payload concentration (Müller et al., 2007).
There are several advantages of implementing NLCs, which are listed below:
○ Higher available space for nutrients compared to SLNs, ○ Enhanced physical stability, ○ Straightforward fabrication and scale-up, ○ Improved dispersibility in an aqueous network, ○ Significant entanglement of lipophilic and hydrophilic nutrients, ○ Controlled particle size,
○ A potent and intricate carrier system compatible with lipophilic agents, ○ The stability of the nano-vehicle minimizes the expulsion of
bioactive ingredients over the storage period, ○ Carriers comprise physiological and biodegradable lipids, ○ Exhibiting low level of cytotoxicity,
○ Firmer confinement of the bioactive inside the nano-vehicle over the storage time, ○ Irregular pattern of internal composition.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Production of NLCs
sections.text:
The manufacturing practices are the same for both SLNs and NLCs. NLCs consist of an unorganized solid lipid network dispersed in liquid lipids and an aqueous moiety together with a single or combination of surfactants. Normally, solid lipids are mixed with liquid lipids in a proportion of 70:30 up to a portion of 99.9:0.1, whereas the surfactant level varies between 1.5% and 5% (w/v) (Beloqui, Solinís, RodríguezGascón, Almeida, & Préat, 2015). The entire solid content of NLCs may reach 95% (w/w). As the level of solid matter increases, more space is available for the bioactive payload; this is a significant advantage both in terms of cost and impact on food. Considerably lower amount of NLCs is required to deliver similar bioactive content in comparison to SLNs. Also, in order to obtain the powder form of the fabricated nanoparticles, water removal from NLCs is a suitable and economical option (Tamjidi et al., 2013). The stability NLC formulations strongly depend on the applied kind and level of the carrier oil. By raising the concentration of the implemented oil, the crystallization and melting temperatures decreased, the polymorphic transformation rate increased, the shape of the particles become spherical and stability of the mixture is enhanced (Ni, Sun, Zhao, & Xia, 2015).
Among the distinct methods applied for the fabrication of NLCs (Table 5), high pressure homogenization plus hot and cold approaches are more practical and preferred over other techniques (Torchilin, 2006, pp. 1–8). In both production approaches, the payload is dissolved in the molten lipid at relatively 5–10 °C higher than its melting temperature. Furthermore, the high pressure homogenization strategy has the scale-up opportunity without the utilization of any organic solvent during the preparation scheme.
Throughout the literature, different substances and mixture of lipids and/or surface active agents were suggested for the fabrication of NLCs. Overall, the implementation of GRAS components, scale up chance and the improved safety of engineered lipid-based vectors make NLCs ideal candidates for further applications in the food industry (Lim, Banerjee, & Önyüksel, 2012; Tamjidi et al., 2013). A detailed review of the fabrication methods of NLCs was released by Tamjidi et al. (2013).
3.3.2. Application of NLCs in the food and nutraceutical fields NLCs has opened tremendous opportunities in different areas of science and industry. Due to their fairly high lading space and excellent stability, NLCs have been successfully implemented in food, pharmaceutical and cosmetic fields. Nonetheless, their application in the production of functional foods are limited in terms of the following reasons:
○ NLCs are well-suited for the retention and delivery of water-insoluble bioactives such as aromas, biocidal agents and drugs into the matrix of aqueous-based foods. However, the accommodation of hydrophilic bioactive materials in lipid nanoparticles is somehow complicated owing to the partitioning behavior of the payload molecules in water medium in the time of preparation (Singh, Dobhal, Jain, Pandit, & Chakraborty, 2010). ○ In order to fabricate safe NLCs on a commercial scale, the utilization of GRAS or food-grade components is inevitable and necessary in the food sector. Most of the materials which are employed in the pharmaceutical industries do not meet the standards for application in the food area. Therefore, more experiments should be performed for the selection of right substances for food practices to dispel the safety concern on the finalized functional food products (Tamjidi et al., 2013). ○ The sensory properties of the functional food should not be significantly altered by the incorporation of bioactive-bearing NLCs in the food network (Du, 2011).
○ Several factors such as pressure, shear, light, freezing, drying and modifications of ionic strength, pH plus environmental storage circumstance affect the stability of NLCs and thus they should be monitored during the fabrication stage (Tamjidi et al., 2013). ○ NLCs should maintain their solid state at the ambient and GI tract temperatures. It is true that both solid and liquid lipid are digested via the enzymes in the body but the digestion rate of liquid lipid is higher than the solid form (McClements & Li, 2010). Moreover, if the bioactive compound is trapped between the tight lipid nanoparticle in the crystalline pattern, its bioavailability may decrease compared to the non-crystalline type.
Nonetheless, NLCs are fantastic candidates for the accommodation of lipophilic nutraceuticals, which may boost their stability, absorption and dispersibility in an aqueous environment like beverages. Hence, a broad range of bioactive compounds has been incorporated in these promising nano-structures for versatile food applications, as given in
Table 5.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Drawbacks and prospects of NLCs
sections.text: In summary, SLNs are intricate bodies with notable benefits and drawbacks compared to other colloidal networks. Due to the lower stability, limited space and undesirable expulsion conditions that SLNs possessed, the NLCs were emerged as efficient alternatives to SLNs to compensate their major problems. They may merge the advantages of various colloidal delivery systems and minimize their limitations. NLCs are appropriate candidates for utilization in the food sector and to deliver lipophilic nutraceuticals, by boosting their stability, bioavailability and dispersibility in aqueous formulations, such as fruit juices, soft drinks and beverages. Alongside all the advantages mentioned for NLCs, some significant issues limit the application of these nanovehicles in the food sector impactably, such as raw material supply plus the environmental determinants. Therefore, much research activities should be conducted to find a solution for these limitations prior to the mass production of NLCs. For instance, by leveraging the knowledge in relation to the formation of particular lipid alterations, the role of surfactants in this process other modifications occurring during storage it is possible to engineer cost-effective systems for industrial purposes.

sections.heading: 4. Characterization and analysis of lipid-based nano-carriers
sections.text: After the preparation step of nanoemulsions, nanoliposomes and NLCs, especially when a new approach is employed, characterization process is imperative to check the quality of the yield. Accordingly, the basic factors which have to be checked are morphology, mainly with respect to its impact on stability as well as liberation rate and entrapment efficiency. The characterization process should be meaningful and quick. Several techniques could be implemented to characterize nanoemulsion, nanoliposome and NLC structures. Each technique has its own pros and cons. Table 6. Highlights the typical and most important parameters plus the analysis types for the lipid-based nanocapsules.

sections.heading: 5. Biological fate and safety of lipid-based nano cargos
sections.text:
Lipid digestion is an intricate combination of biochemical and physiochemical processes taking place within the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). The presence of naturally occurring salts in the buccal cavity impose considerable changes in the stability of lipid-based nanostructures via the alteration of the ionic strength of the matrix. Moreover, mucin, present in saliva has the propensity to cause aggregation of the nanodroplets through the depletion flocculation or bridging phenomena. As the oil droplets reach the stomach, their aggregation status is altered owing to the extreme low pH along with the shear circumstances. Thus, a trace amount of hydrolysis occurs as a result of the gastric lipase but it should be noted that the main digestion is carried out by the pancreatic lipase within the small intestine. The

role of the bile salts available in the intestinal juice is to enable the enzyme binding process by displacing the primary emulsifier elements from the oil-water interface (McClements, 2018). During the lipolysis phase, free fatty acids (FFAs) and monoacylglycerols (MGs) are formed and aggregate on the oil surface which later halt the lipolysis reaction due to the displacement of the lipase enzyme via the boosted surface activity of FFAs and MGs. These digested entities are removed by the bile salts through the solubilization process in the mixed micelles. In addition, calcium ions are capable of forming insoluble soaps from the FFAs and removing them from the surface of the droplets. Ultimately, yields from the lypolisis together with the lipophilic core materials are solubilized in complex micelles or unilamellar phospholipid vesicles which makes them ready to be absorbed by the intestinal cells (Jafari, Katouzian, Rajabi, & Ganje, 2017; McClements, 2018).
Also, Pyo et al. (2017) stated that lipid nanostructures (here SLNs & NLCs) enter the intestine without the dispersion by bile salts owing to their extra small size. Later, the colipase or lipase binds to the surface of the lipid nanostructure and induce degradation. As a result, mono and diglycerides are formed which carry surfactant properties. Then, both the core material and the lipid structure are solubilized in micelles and these micelles are ready for the absorption process (lymphatic absorption). For the development of the generation of this micelle, lipids with higher levels of monoglycerids should be employed to prepare the lipid nanoparticles (Fig. 3).
Herein, it seems necessary to review some recent studies considering the in vitro and in vivo experiments to better understand the impact of lipid-based nanostructures on the body.

sections.heading: 5.1. In vitro assays
sections.text:
Yu and Huang (2013) conducted a research on evaluating the toxicity of nanoemulsions and reported that nanodroplets with the diameter below 200 nm induced no toxicity in Caco-2 cells (intestinal
cells). Yet, loss of living cells was observed for HepG2 cell lines (liver) following exposure to nanoemulsions which does not happen by common emulsions. Puglia et al. (2017) produced a sesamol containing formulation via the NLCs to be applied as a topical agent. Percutaneous absorption through the human skin was done in order to test the distribution and to evaluate the antioxidant capacity. To sum up, in vitro results demonstrated that NLCs enabled a controlled diffusion of sesamol through the skin and provided a long-term antioxidant activity of sesamol. Wu et al. (2017) evaluated the antioxidant and cytotoxicity characteristics of the catechin-loaded nanoliposomes consisted phosphatidylcholine. The cytotoxicity was observed using the Caco-2 cells which suggested that only at high doses nanoliposomes were toxic (0.025mg/mL). Furthermore, higher cytotoxicity was recorded after 36 h compared to 24 h at the same levels.

sections.heading: 5.2. In vivo assays
sections.text:
Xing et al. (2017) designed and fabricated a novel near-infrared probe having high fluorescence (iDSPE) and embedded it in nanoliposomes with different sizes (100 nm and 400 nm) to monitor the cellular uptake and in vivo bioavailability. The results indicated that the loaded liposomes with lower size were accumulated in the tumor tissues, while the bodies with the size of 400 nm accumulated in spleen and liver. Therefore, the size of the engineered nanoliposomes play an important role in determining the biodistribution of the nanoliposmes which should be further studied. Also, Mohammadi, Pezeshki, Abbasi, Ghanbarzadeh, and Hamishehkar (2017) prepared vitamin D3-loaded NLCs with the aim of fortifying the food and beverages. Besides, they performed an in vivo study on male orally-administered wistar rats to measure the final vitamin D3 in their plasma and to determine the bioavailability. As a result, this type of delivery applied faster appearance of this vitamin in plasma and induced a prolonged vitamin D3 plasma concentration. In another study, Coradini et al. (2015) encased

In summary, the nano-engineered complex did not alter the hepatic biomarkers, mainly ALP, AST and ALT and thus this matrix was safe in regard to hepatotoxicity and can be applied to treat inflammation disorders including arthritis.

sections.heading: 6. Future trends
sections.text:
As nanoscale vehicles and particles exhibit new features due to their extra small size they may have unforeseen effects on the human body and may even accumulate in different parts of the body and organs. Also, long-term usage of these brand new nanocompartments is still unknown to the food industry. Thus, prior to the mass production of these nanomaterials in the food industry and human consumption the products must first be evaluated by in vitro, in vivo and even in silico tests to assess their outcome and further usage (Katouzian & Jafari, 2016).
Currently, there are many marketed nano-lipid based products in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic sectors, yet in the food industry some of these products include Coatsome™ (a phospholipid-based building block that forms liposome micelles when suspended in water) (Peters et al., 2016), Aquanova NovaSol® (nanoemulsion incorporating liposoluble vitamins and ω-3 fatty acids as well),1 Fabuless® (a nanoemulsion which retards the digestion process till it reaches the lower part of the small intestine) (McClements, 2015), Canola active oil® from the Shemen industries in Israel (nanosized self-assembled liquid lipids for the retention of phytosterols),2 Asia Food beverage® in Thailand (producing nanoliposomes for food applications)3 and Curcosome® (Quercetin-bearing nanoliposomes).4 For the current and state-of-the-art applications of the nanomaterials in the food sector, the interested readers are referred to http://www.nanotechproject.org.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: The successful development of nanostructured delivery systems has thoroughly transformed the food and nutraceutical sector. The immense surface area per unit mass of the nano-scale compounds enhances their biological activity amazingly. Nanoformulations have revealed to improve the solubility and bioaccessibility of lipid-based bioactive food ingredients via in vitro and in vivo studies. The nanoencapsulation bodies, such as nanoemulsion, nanoliposomes and NLCs are especially compatible with food systems owing to their high stability in the food matrix as well as being stable in the digestive system. Currently, the probable adverse health effects of nanomaterials are still an enigma and need to be further studied. Moreover, the regulatory framework of nanofoods is still in the development stage. The operation of lipid-based nanoencapsulation systems is yet to be explored in both food products and the body as well. Future trends for these nano-vehicles may cover the investigations regarding interactions between the food constituents and the incorporated nanoformulations as well as the physicochemical characteristics of the engineered nano-carriers.

referenceMentions.context: Encapsulation technique has entered the field of food science for more than 60 years as an efficient solution to shield the bioactive components against external environmental factors and/or unwanted chemical interactions until release is desired (Sekhon, 2010).
Besides, the availability of digestible lipid facilitates the intestinal absorption of bioactives since they are able to solubilize and carry the hydrophobic molecules (McClements, 2012).
Hence, the foregoing advantages hold lipid-based nanocarriers as robust and flexible delivery vectors (Tamjidi et al., 2013).
In the food sector, nanoliposomes are typically implemented to deliver protein assemblies, vitamins, enzymes, antioxidants, aromas and natural colors (Mozafari, 2005).
As reported by (McClements, 2004), emulsions are categorized into micro- (10–100 nm), mini (nano)- (100–1000 nm), and macro-emulsions (0.

Nano-emulsions (submicron-size droplets) is placed among normal and microemulsions, which fits in the size range of 50–200 nm (transparent) or up to 500 nm that presents a blurred image (McClements, 2012).

The discussed methods have several limitations including consumption of high levels of surfactants plus the accurate selection of surfactant–cosurfactant admix and they are not appropriate for further applications in large-scale industrial practices (Seekkuarachchi et al., 2006).

In addition, nanoemulsions may undergo unwanted phenomena, such as Ostwald ripening (Rao & McClements, 2011), flocculation, membrane permeability and further liberation of bioactives, gelling, creaming, and particle attraction during storage (McClements, 2012), however by choosing the right type of surfactant and controlling the surface charges these phenomena can be minimized.
1C, lipid-based nanocarriers in the food sector comprise Solid Lipid Nanoparticles (SLNs) and Nanostructured Lipid Carriers (NLCs) (Fang et al., 2008).
NLCs possess many amorphous crystals within their structure, which establish a larger room for the bioactive molecules and lower the expulsion rate of bioactive compounds (Tamjidi et al. 2013).
Yet, scholars prefer NLCs over SLNs owing to their lipid anti-recrystallization attributes that prevent the expulsion of bioactive payload (Müller et al., 2007).
All the aforementioned models provide the circumstances for the formation of compact particle dispersions (> 30–95%) plus the augmented payload concentration (Müller et al., 2007).
Also, in order to obtain the powder form of the fabricated nanoparticles, water removal from NLCs is a suitable and economical option (Tamjidi et al., 2013).

Overall, the implementation of GRAS components, scale up chance and the improved safety of engineered lipid-based vectors make NLCs ideal candidates for further applications in the food industry (Lim, Banerjee, & Önyüksel, 2012; Tamjidi et al., 2013).
Therefore, more experiments should be performed for the selection of right substances for food practices to dispel the safety concern on the finalized functional food products (Tamjidi et al., 2013).
○ The sensory properties of the functional food should not be significantly altered by the incorporation of bioactive-bearing NLCs in the food network (Du, 2011).

○ Several factors such as pressure, shear, light, freezing, drying and modifications of ionic strength, pH plus environmental storage circumstance affect the stability of NLCs and thus they should be monitored during the fabrication stage (Tamjidi et al., 2013).

Ultimately, yields from the lypolisis together with the lipophilic core materials are solubilized in complex micelles or unilamellar phospholipid vesicles which makes them ready to be absorbed by the intestinal cells (Jafari, Katouzian, Rajabi, & Ganje, 2017; McClements, 2018).

Currently, there are many marketed nano-lipid based products in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic sectors, yet in the food industry some of these products include CoatsomeTM (a phospholipid-based building block that forms liposome micelles when suspended in water) (Peters et al., 2016), Aquanova NovaSol (nanoemulsion incorporating liposoluble vitamins and ω-3 fatty acids as well),(1) Fabuless (a nanoemulsion which retards the digestion process till it reaches the lower part of the small intestine) (McClements, 2015), Canola active oil from the Shemen industries in Israel (nanosized self-assembled liquid lipids for the retention of phytosterols),(2) Asia Food beverage in Thailand (producing nanoliposomes for food applications)(3) and Curcosome (Quercetin-bearing nanoliposomes).

metadata.abstractText: Background: The encapsulation and liberation technologies for bioactive food ingredients has opened the door to innovative and significant applications in food, nutrition, and pharmaceutical fields via the employment of nanotechnology. Coating materials in the formulation of nanocapsules are mostly lipid, carbohydrate or proteinbased. The nanoencapsulation procedure in the food and nutraceutical areas involves the incorporation of natural ingredients, such as volatile additives, polyphenols, aromas, colors, vitamins, enzymes, oils and antimicrobial compounds in nano-sized capsules, providing the opportunities for higher stability and retention for the sensitive molecules against decomposition and loss of nutritional value during the production process or delivery along with offering a sustained release. Scope and approach: This review highlights the most recent nanoencapsulation advancements along with the formulations mainly based on lipid components; i.e., nanoemulsions, nanoliposomes and nanostructured lipid carriers in terms of preparation strategies, their classes, composition, attributes, analysis techniques, worked examples, and implementation in functional foods along with their upcoming evolution and future trends. Key findings and conclusions: Nanocapsules with lipid formulations are possible alternatives to micro-sized carriers owing to the enormous surface area and the following features which they offer, such as improved solubility, high bioavailability and establishment of sustained liberation of the nanoencapsulated food constituents and nutraceuticals.
